bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 8, 1950

div1.p: Kean comments on a book by Powell that cites Reed's work and that of other physicians.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 8, 1950
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Sunday
8 Jan. '50
Dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Gen. A.G. Love Med Corps Retd
Took me to Walter Reed on the 5th
to see Gen. Ireland. His condition is
lamentable. He cannot any longer sit up
or apparently use his muscles in any
way or say a word. He did smile when
he saw me which was a great comfort
to me for I feared he might not know
me. Gen. Love was at Walter Reed to
hear your address which he said was
wonderful, and said that the hall was
jammed, as many as could crowd in.
He wished to speak to you, but you were
so surrounded that he had to give it up
and come away. I hope that you were
able to have a talk with Surg. Gen. Bliss
AC
K
2
If you did not I will ask Siler to write
you about the Tablet. Before putting
Powell's book “Bring Out Your Dead” on the
shelf I wanted to make a few comments
He mentions Walter Reed in the preface
and gives him credit for having discovered
the transmission of yellow fever by the
female mosquito, which Reed never claimed
and which we know is not true. I always
✓ Think, as you know, that the word demonstrated
should be used for his great accomplish
ment. The name of Carlos Finlay is not men-
tioned. Of course this will enrage our Cuban
friends, and destroy the value of his book
for them. Powell is such a well informed man
that they will regard the error as intentional.
There seem to have been quite a number of second
attacks, and in some the second was fatal.
Dr. Finlay regarded second attacks as very rare
and I suppose in such cases the first fever
was malarial or from some other cause.

There were some fine doctors in Phila
Currie for instance and fat Hutchinson
✓ the Post Physician who accepted Cur-
rie's rational treatment, and might pro-
bably have been saved if he had stayed
quietly in bed instead of getting up and
going down stairs and doing some writing
during the remission. And Deveze the
french man who had learned rational
treatment of the disease in his practice
in the West Indies. Was it not noble the
way that Girard supported him at Bush
Hill Hospital against all the fulminations
of Dr. Rush and his followers. I think
that Powell has done a great work in
bringing to popular notice the nobility
of Stephen Girard, and Helm, the Major
Clarkson and his committee and the many
brave men who stayed in the city to keep
things going and provide food and money
AC
K
4
and workmen to meet each emergency
as it arose. The way the committee
backed up Girard and Helm at Bush
Hill and provided whatever they called
for makes a fine story. I was sorry to
read that Benjamin Rush got his inspira-
tion as to treatment from a book by Dr.
John Mitchell on his experience in Virginia
in 1741 (page 77). The cool way in which
Rush and his followers disregarded the
✓ great experience✓ of the French doctors Deveze
La Roche and Menge's is surprising and
lamentable. I never read any of La Roche
but remember that Walter Reed brought his
fat 2 volumes to Cuba and was always
quoting them. Just who was responsible
✓ for the marvelous efficacy of the American
treatment in Cuba? rest in bed from the
beginning, no medicine and no food,
until all fever left and then not made.
You will remember that the mortality of
5
such Americans as were under
Army care and treatment, was only
about 1/3 of that of the Spanish
laborers in Havana. Reed took much
interest in the treatment of our cases
but I do not recall that he made any
changes in it or suggestions regarding
it. I would be interested to know
what La Roche had to say regarding
treatment. The Cuban doctors always
wanted to give a Saline purgative
first thing.

Well this is enough about Powell's
book. It is well written and indexed
and shows much labor and discrim-
ination.

I think that both Cornelia and I can now
be discharged from sick Report. We
send great regards to you and Mrs H
